list_definition.definition: to make wet with drops of liquid, mud etc, especially suddenly and accidentally

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: A passing car splashed my coat (with water).

list_definition.definition: to (cause to) fly about in drops
to fall or move with splashes

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The children were splashing in the sea.

list_definition.definition: to display etc in a place, manner etc that will be noticed

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: Posters advertising the concert were splashed all over the wall.

list_definition.definition: a scattering of drops of liquid or the noise made by this

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He fell in with a loud splash.
There was a splash of mud on her dress.

list_ex_of_english: Who hasn't seen images of gang-related violence splashed all over the evening news?
Five years ago, that would not have been the case—the story would have been splashed across the headlines.
Then, under a crash of electronic screeches, blood splashed onto the inside of the glass door; and one of the boys ran terrified into view.
I suppose this battle started when the first person jumped on a horse and a passing pedestrian got splashed.
I regret that those comments have been splashed around widely in media in this country.
A woman in my area splashed vinegar in her eye while making a salad dressing for a dinner party and called an ambulance.
Footsteps, engines, birds, animals and splashing rain are but a few categories of natural sound sources that each have their own set of behavioural and synthesis modelling complexities.
Lamps positioned below the transparent tanks illuminate patterns on the surface of the water as it ripples and splashes.
